ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A broad understanding of comparative anatomy. More or less what you'd expect.

I gained an understanding of the many organ systems which make up the bodies of vertebrates, from the perspective of their morphologies and the cellular and evolutionary processes which led to their development both as novel structures in evolutionary time and as complex systems within a single organism.
Knowledge of anatomy in a developmental sense for many different systems across many different taxa
so much! the course content is incredibly interesting. We essentially studied the evolutionary history of vertebrates, from the developmental and comparative perspectives.
Learned about comparative developmental anatomy
Basic anatomy of vertebrates and what development/evolution led to these characteristics.
I learned about the evolutionary and developmental underpinnings of anatomy of extant vertebrates.
Development and evolution of different organ systems across vertebrates.
I learned so much about anatomy and how anatomical features are similar and different based on organism. It was cool to get this through an evolutionary perspective.

I learned about how the physiology of placental mammals compares to other vertebrates. The course also provided a good review of embryology and a solid foundation for understanding basic devo-evo principles. I also learned about which animals I need to examine, and in what order, to build a comparative perspective across vertebrates.
Recognizing the evolutionary and developmental processes that create vertebrates.
In depth analysis of development anatomy of several vertebrate clades all the way up to humans

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The essay-exams were strange and seemed to focus only on small aspects of the broader course.

This course is very information-dense, and it can be difficult to keep track of all relevant facts within a given lecture. However, the fact that lectures were recorded allowed for any missed details to be relearned at a later date, and Professor Wagner's willingness to respond to questions, and his ability to answer effectively, meant that critical information was never truly slipping through a student's fingers.

nothing. the content is interesting, the assignments fair and fun. I loved the essay format, gives me time to think about things, do additional research and truly learn, instead of rote memorization. Sadly Prof. Wagner won't be teaching at Yale any more. The amount of research literature paper incorporated was awesome pretty cool.

Strengths: Interesting lectures, lots of interdisciplinary connections pulled from other areas of study
Weaknesses: Sometimes disorganized, largely due to remote nature of course and teaching/learning across different time zones, lecture slides didn't always correspond to the slated lecture session (ie: sometimes we'd cover half the lecture slides in one class or two sets of lecture slides in one class, it made reviewing material for papers a little more confusing)

Content is very interesting! Students can take content at their own pace. Essays are a great way to check for understanding while also letting the student decide what info is interesting/meaningful to them. I definitely got the most out of the lecture while also being enrolled in the lab.

I think that a weakness of this course would be that the lecture style was slightly confusing. This made it harder for me to understand the concepts. Despite this though, I feel as though Gunter did his best in teaching this course.
The material is really interesting, but is sometimes presented in a disorganized manner.
I really appreciated the essay format of exams that allowed students to think through answers rather than memorize anything.

Overall, I thought the teaching was clear and the lectures included enough repetition for me to memorize the necessary phylogenetic relationships. The mini summary slides following more complicated topics were helpful.
The material was very interesting, but I think having only 3 assignments didn't give enough chances for students to show their knowledge and skill.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The virtual lecture format served this course very well, as it allowed both for synchronous time to ask questions and asynchronous time to review recordings and grasp all details of the paper. The open book essay assessments also effectively allowed students to demonstrate their grasp of all the content in the class without fearing that a small detail slipping their minds could have catastrophic consequences. However, the structure of the Zoom lectures made the TFs feel unapproachable, and they seemed to have no role in the class at all.

I like the concept of essays as a substitute for exams, but I wasn't a huge fan of the grading. If they are going to be graded on a relatively rigid rubric, I would've preferred to have the expectations made clearer in advance.
nothing, I think everything was fine. Even if Prof. Wagner isn't the most tech savvy person out there, he managed okay.
Appreciated the exams being turned into papers, it was extremely helpful and I feel like I learned just as much through that form of assessment
The recorded lectures were a great help to me because I took this class at the same time as another, so I was able to go back and catch up on the material I missed.

I believe this course generally involves exams as assessments rather than essays. While the essay topics were interesting, I sometimes felt that exams would have been a more appropriate mode of assessment for the style of course.
I appreciated that the lectures were recorded with transcripts because I wasnt always able to make it to the live lecture.

I thought this class was very considerate to the difficulties of learning during the pandemic. I noticed that many people were choosing to watch the lectures asynchronously and the professor never expressed any doubt or frustration against the students for doing this. I really appreciated this, especially because it often is not a given that a professor will be generous, especially a professor in STEM.

Learned a lot in a low stress environment, really really enjoyed this class. Breath of fresh air.
I listened to pre-recorded lectures and had no problem.

Prof Wagner decided to use short essays to evaluate us instead of exams given that everything would be open note. I thought this was a great idea and definitely increased my level of engagement and understanding of the material. Rather than just memorizing facts/names of bones/muscles/etc, I felt I have a good understanding of the evolutionary progress and developmental processes that take place. I would strongly suggest that the professor next semester consider this method instead  i think it would be hugely beneficial to learning

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is a perfect synthesis of the cross-species comparisons which are usually foregrounded in evolutionary biology, the temporal analysis of individual specimens and species which forms the basis of developmental biology, and the in-depth morphological examinations which spark the initial interest in organismal-level biology and the practice of medicine in so many students. Students seeking one of these biological approaches without the presence of the others will likely find enough of what they desire in this course to enjoy it, but students who seek all three will find exactly what they are looking for.
If you are interested in medicine or vertebrate anatomy, definitely.
Yep! Very interesting content
Yes

Highly recommend! Professor Wagner is clearly very intelligent but not overbearingly so, he points out the most interesting aspects of each topic and gives a good background for the student to understand what evidence led to each of these scientific discoveries. He is also very funny in his own way. A good idea to take it with lab, which is more work but extremely fun!

Yes!  It provided me with a new perspective of anatomy.  Instead of simply memorizing how different organ systems work, we learned about the evolution and development of the vertebrate body.  This gave me a greater overall understanding of anatomy, and a longer lasting knowledge that will serve me well in vet school.
I would recommend this course to a student if they are majoring in E&EB.
Yes, provided youre ready to do a lot of memorization!
Yes! Its a great course, and Prof. Wagner did a great job teaching the material.
Sure, although if you're not interested in the topic, it might be pretty dry.
Yes. The course was well-taught and thr subject material was very interesting.
Yes, its a lot of information but its really interesting if you engage with the material. It reminds you how cool evolution really is

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lecture
Live and recorded
